verses.text: Watching for riches consumeth the flesh, And the care thereof driveth away sleep.
Watching care will not let \add a man\add* slumber, As a sore disease breaketh sleep.
The rich hath great labour in gathering riches together; And when \add he\add* resteth, he is filled with his delicates.
The poor laboureth in \add his\add* poor estate; And when he leaveth off, he is \add still\add* needy.
He that loveth gold shall not be justified, And he that followeth corruption shall have enough \add thereof\add*.
Gold hath been the ruin of many, And their destruction was present.
It is a stumblingblock unto them that sacrifice unto it, And every fool shall be taken therewith.
Blessed \add is\add* the rich that is found without blemish, And hath not gone after gold.
Who is he? and we will call him blessed: For wonderful \add things\add* hath he done among his people.
Who hath been tried thereby, and found perfect? Then let \add him\add* glory. Who might offend, and hath not offended? Or done evil, and hath not done \add it?\add*
His goods shall be established, And the congregation shall declare his alms.
If thou sit at a bountiful table, Be not greedy upon it, And say not, \add There is\add* much \add meat\add* on it.
Remember that a wicked eye \add is\add* an evil \add thing:\add* \add And\add* what is created more wicked than an eye? Therefore it weepeth upon every occasion.
Stretch not thine hand whithersoever it looketh, And thrust \add it\add* not with him into the dish.
Judge of \add thy\add* neighbour by thyself: And be discreet in every point.
Eat, as \add it becometh\add* a man, those \add things\add* which are set before thee; And devour not, lest thou be hated.
Leave off first for mannersâ€™ sake; And be not unsatiable, lest thou offend.
When thou sittest among many, Reach not thine hand out first of all.
A very little \add is\add* sufficient for a man well nurtured, And he fetcheth not his wind short upon his bed.

Sound sleep \add cometh\add* of moderate eating: He riseth early, and his wits \add are\add* with him: \add But\add* the pain of watching, and choler, and pangs of the belly, \add are\add* with an unsatiable man.
And if thou hast been forced to eat, Arise, go forth, vomit, and thou shalt have rest.
\add My\add* son, hear me, and despise me not, And at the last thou shalt find as I told thee: In all thy works be quick, So shall there no sickness come unto thee.
\add Whoso is\add* liberal of \add his\add* meat, men shall speak well of him; And the report of his good housekeeping \add will be\add* believed.
\add But\add* against \add him that is\add* a niggard of \add his\add* meat the \add whole\add* city shall murmur; And the testimonies of his niggardness \add shall\add* not \add be\add* doubted of.
Shew not thy valiantness in wine; For wine hath destroyed many.
The furnace proveth the edge by dipping: So doth wine the hearts of the proud by drunkeness.
Wine \add is\add* as good as life to a man, if it be drunk moderately: What life \add is then\add* to \add a man\add* that is without wine? For it was made to make men glad.
Wine measurably drunk \add and\add* in season \add Bringeth\add* gladness of the heart, and cheerfulness of the mind:
\add But\add* wine drunken with excess \add maketh\add* bitterness of the mind, With brawling and quarrelling.
Drunkenness increaseth the rage of a fool till \add he\add* offend: It diminisheth strength, and maketh wounds.
Rebuke not \add thy\add* neighbour at the wine, And despise him not in his mirth: Give him no despiteful words, And press not upon him with urging him \add to drink\add*.
